zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message: How does this reconcile the ordering of concurrent updates? It seems like we send in a fixed set of attributes to set which may be stale by the time they are set due to the retries above? Put another way could the updates that caused a ConcurrentUpdateError here be newer and more accurate in which case we should just stop?

I believe the intention of this method is that it's called with semi-immutable values.  We're calling it with attributes like the change dependencies or the files list.  The git dependencies and files are set by the drivers; if more than one of them tried to perform an update, they should end up with the same data (a different set of git depends or files is a different change in git).
The commit dependencies (ie depends-on) may be set by pipeline managers, but similarly, they should come to the same conclusion.

Two cache set events could be setting different attributes though.  By the time we get through this loop, we should have read in the new attributes from the other actor, and added our own (if they are different, and if they are the same or overlap, we should have harmlessly overwritten them).

Here we assume the ConcurrentUpdateError means we should simply reread from the cache as it will be up to date. This is different than above where we try to set attributes in a retry loop and defers to the other update.
See above question about updated change attributes. I think this has potentially similar concerns?
Or into a connection base class...
Should we think about refactoring this retry proceduce into the change cache itself?

Done in 808612. The way we update the change is always a little different between drivers. This means we have to pass a function that's updating the change.

As described in the other file, I think this test should actually be as follows:

    def test_cache_sync(self):
        other_cache = DummyChangeCache(self.zk_client, DummyConnection())

        key = 'foo foo'
        change = DummyChange("project", {key: "bar"})
        self.cache.set(key, change)
        self.assertIsNotNone(other_cache.get(key))

        change_other = other_cache.get(key)
        change_other.number = 123
        other_cache.set(key, change_other)

        import time; time.sleep(0.5)
        self.assertEqual(change.number, 123)

        other_cache.delete(key)
        self.assertIsNone(self.cache.get(key))

The time.sleep is a placeholder; it should probably actually be an iterate_timeout that waits for change.number == 123.

This does 2 things (both of which fail in the current code).

1) We use a key which requires quoting.
2) We test that a other_cache.set() updates our local self.cache object (ie, we set a data watch on the initial self.cache.set()).

This is the form of key that the gerrit driver uses:

  key = str((event.change_number, event.patch_number))

Maybe even consider using that type of key here as that has a number of things that need quoting.

zuul/model.py.message: Methods are called (de)serialize() since toDict() are already used for other purposes. The main problem is the toDict() of the Change class here as it currently seems to return an executor specific representation.
This should probably moved to a separate change after 805844 as it's not JSON serializable in the current form.
Why is project missing from here when we have it in the serialize method?

The project of a change is supplied via the init and is immutable. However, if we create a new change object from serialized data we need the project name in order to create it with the correct project instance.

A better name for the serialize/deserialize methods would be toDict/updateFromDict, but that is already used for the executor specific serialization.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
That might be a way to untangle the permanent vs temporary data confusion we have here (git dependencies are immutable aspects of a change(patchset); header dependencies are mutable, in that saying Depends-On: foo could mean foo patchset 1, or foo patchset 2 depending on when it was resolved).  Storing the mutable references on the change object always seemed awkward.

But maybe we can store only the immutable references on the change object, and then have the pipeline manager determine the mutable references and store the results (as cache keys, since we know this is going into ZK too) on queue items, then have the pipeline manager pull the actual change objects out of the cache from those keys as needed?

I think storing the mutable dependencies on the queue item might complicate things regarding the "refresh_deps" flag. Currently this is set in the onChangeUpdated() method of the scheduler by looping over the cached changes in all sources.

If the mutable needed changes are part of the queue item we can no longer access them from outside the run handler. I'm not 100% sure about his, but it seems as if we'd need to dispatch an event to all tenants/pipelines in order to refresh the dependencies. We could turn this around by making the pipeline manager check if the needed change is still up-to-date. But that could cause unnecessary access of the ZK change cache.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: Can you elaborate on the purpose of the pipeline change cache?  It's obviously to avoid us having to go to the driver change cache, but why is that going to be expensive?  Will using the driver cache always involve ZK calls?

Makes sense.  I think some of this is worth memorializing in a comment.  Maybe something like:

    # A small local cache to avoid hitting the ZK-based connection change cache for multiple
    # hits in the same pipeline run.

Yes, this is basically to avoid the ZK call to check if a change is up-to-date as we only have a single scheduler ATM.

When we have the pipeline state in Zookeeper we probably want to completely clear the cache at the end of each pipeline run, so we are only using the cache to avoid multiple ZK hits for the same cache key.
Do we need to sanity check that change.cache_key == key here?
I'd say no as I see no special reason to do so, but open to be convinced otherwise.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/puppet/kuber.message:
First, this logic doesn't make any sense.  If we're going to use "kube_upgrade_state == kubernetes.KUBE_UPGRADING_KUBELETS" as the test, then there's no point in checking kube_host_upgrade.status.

I'm concerned that _get_kubeadm_kubelet_version() could end up reporting the new version of kubelet before we actually want the new version, since any call to update_host_config() after the k8s upgrade starts would end up picking up the new version of kubelet.

I wonder if it might make more sense to transition kube_host_upgrade.status from kubernetes.KUBE_HOST_UPGRADING_KUBELET to a new state KUBE_HOST_UPGRADED_KUBELET, and we could test for that new state here.  That way we have a per-host indication that kubelet has been successfully upgraded.

When we complete the upgrade we could go in and clear out all the per-host kube_host_upgrade.status values so that they're blank in prep for the next k8s upgrade.

No, BACKUP_ACTION_PRE_ETCD_BACKUP is an interface between paybookconfig and sysinv.

    BACKUP_ACTION_PRE_ETCD_BACKUP: [APP_LIFECYCLE_MODE_AUTO,
                                    APP_LIFECYCLE_TYPE_OPERATION,
                                    APP_LIFECYCLE_TIMING_PRE,
                                    APP_ETCD_BACKUP],

The removal of webhook is presented to the end user as a recovery operation for Portieris.  I do not want to restore the webhook here, or in post etcd-backup, if it was absent when pre etd-backup hook ran.
Good point, updated.
I think we need a place to store this information during the pre_etcd_backup. Any idea for that?

The existence of helm user override for ReapplyAdmissionWebhook could work for that purpose.  Since we agreed to reserve it for this operation I think we can use it store the logic in etcd backup.  In the pre etcd-backup if the mutating webhook exists then both the helm override can be added and the webhook removed.  Then in both post etcd-backup and post restore, if the helm override is defined then it can be poked with a new value, the portieris application reapplied to restore the webhook, and finally the helm override removed.

Helm is upgrading the chart when the value of ReapplyAdmissionWebhook is changed.  So that I do not expect the helm post-upgrade hook to fire if this value and set but not changed (unless by some other means the upgrade is triggered).

So instead of just creating it, I think we would want to always set it to something "true" - a string that is not "false" or nil.  I think nanoseconds would work.

doc/source/admin/config-rbac.rst.message:
Possible re-write:

Creating an instance which uses a security group shared through RBAC, but only
specifying the network ID when calling Nova will not work currently. In such
cases Nova will check if the given security group exists in Neutron before it
creates a port in the given network. The problem with that is that Nova asks
only for the security groups filtered by the project_id thus it will not get
the shared security group back from the Neutron API. See `bug 1942615
<https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1942615>`__ for details.
To workaround the issue, the user needs to create a port in Neutron first, and
then pass that port to Nova:

This code returns value or raises exception in `while` loop clause, thus `else` clause seems to be redundant:
```

LOG.error('Failed to execute remote command.')
raise exceptions.MgmtDriverRemoteCommandError()
```

Thank you for your comment. This is a for-else statement. The else statement will be executed if there is no return or break executed in the for statement. If the try statement is executed successfully, the return will be executed. If an exception occurs in the try statement, the exception is only caught, and no exception is thrown. It will retry again until the number of retry runs out. Therefore, if the number of retry runs out and the return is not executed, the else statement will be executed, so the else statement is not redundant.

yes, I meant "solution" for the CI issue

I checked logs from failed and passed jobs once again. I think that the difference is in ovn package: when it passed it was ovn2.13.x86_64 20.12.0-135.el8 and when it failed it was ovn2.13-20.12.0-161.el8.x86_64 - most likely ovn2.13-20.12.0-161.el8.x86_64 can't work properly with openvswitch2.12 which was installed on the node initially (and as never restarted, used for all the time).

Just a comment.  We should ensure that the rt version is always the same as the std version but just with the preempt-rt patchset also applied.  I don't like the thought of us using two different base kernels.  Let me know if the linux-yocto trees don't support that approach or uses a different tactic.

This is the same base, as is described in the branch names 'v5.10/standard/base' and 'v5.10/standard/preempt-rt/base'.  So 'v5.10' tracks verbatum Greg KH's stable updates, 'v5.10/standard' will be Greg KH's stable kernel with a set of standard patches (ie, patches common to all supported ARCH and BSP), 'v5.10/standard/preempt-rt' adds the preempt_rt patchset, and so on. So this is consumed in the same was as the Yocto Project consumes this source for the -standard and -rt ktypes.
Please add a comment to remind us what branch or tag this sha comes from.

Yes, and I think intentionally we don't want to remove non-active replicas in error states at this place, because the method is trying to fix these.

My first attempt of fixing was adding a guard here to avoid an IndexError. But I came to the conclusion that the place with filtering at periodic_share_replica_update() is better, because it is

If we have a replica that doesn't have a 'active' data source, shouldn't we set this replica to error? This method was created to update replica states, and it expect replicas in 'sync', 'out_of_sync' or in 'error' status.

We might want to grab this *before* we hand off to the application -- there's a chance application code could wrap it or otherwise swap it out.

Might also want to choose a name that doesn't shadow a built-in.

True, but it also why I use eventlet.input and not the wsgi.input. They start off the same https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/master/eventlet/wsgi.py#L720

And I think we tend to use wsgi.input so if we change it out the other still exists. But yeah, doesn't hurt to pull it out, just in case. The env is generated in handle_one_request should should exist wefore we run handle_one_response above.
I could see us hitting this in tests -- do we ever get here in practice? I would've hoped eventlet would *always* set up the input...
To be honest, no I don't think we would get here in practice.. esp if we pull out the input so there is no chance we've done anything or lost it down in the swift layer.
If you're running https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/pull/578 the server will have already tried to drain the body by the time this method finishes

We do some funky things with sending zero-length chunks mid-stream: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1496636

So I guess there may be a way we'll fire off a response between receiving data and footers, or between footers and commit, and the *object-server* will fire off a 400 Bad Request when it tries to parse the next MIME doc (if sent) as a new request. IDK that we can avoid that short of *actually speaking HTTP* though.

I changed it. Please let me know if that makes sense or if I should change it in the "parameter_defaults" section in all neutron related environment files.
Thx, I did it like that now.
this should go in an environment file and not in a service definition.

You'll find that you can mix values for defaults. If you want to do this automagically, something that might work for you is to change the heat template to follow a set/unset pattern and in the OVN plugin template (deployment/neutron/neutron-plugin-ml2-ovn.yaml) set the hiera to neutron::dhcp_agent_notification to false if the heat parameter remains unset or the value of the parameter if it is set. In the ML2/OVS plugin case you would have neutron::dhcp_agent_notification have true as the default or use the value of the DhcpAgentNotification parameter. The problem you might run into there is if there are still situations where you need a DHCP agent in an ML2/OVN deployment. Doing something automagically then might be a little trickier - but chances are that is something that can easily be handled by setting DhcpAgentNotification in the environment file where the value of OS::TripleO::NeutronDhcpAgent is actually set to the dhcp agent template.

*But* you could just do the easy thing: change DhcpAgentNotification's value to false in neutron-base.yaml and in the environment files for enabling ML2/OVS, set it to true and you're done.
Thx. As I don't know how to do boolean value to be "True", "False" or "unset" in templates, I made this easy thing :)

kernel-modules/intel-ice/files/0001-Fix-.message: Still need this to be researched.  Did earlier 3.10 kernels set CONFIG_NET_RX_BUSY_POLL?

But just as important is the why:

commit 28d0dc9176be85c5f7f505b0a255c0a9d0c320b6
Author: Sebastian Andrzej Siewior <bigeasy@linutronix.de>
Date:   Sat May 27 19:02:06 2017 +0200

    net/core: disable NET_RX_BUSY_POLL on RT

    napi_busy_loop() disables preemption and performs a NAPI poll. We can't acquire
    sleeping locks with disabled preemption so we would have to work around this
    and add explicit locking for synchronisation against ksoftirqd.
    Without explicit synchronisation a low priority process would "own" the NAPI
    state (by setting NAPIF_STATE_SCHED) and could be scheduled out (no
    preempt_disable() and BH is preemptible on RT).
    In case a network packages arrives then the interrupt handler would set
    NAPIF_STATE_MISSED and the system would wait until the task owning the NAPI
    would be scheduled in again.
    Should a task with RT priority busy poll then it would consume the CPU instead
    allowing tasks with lower priority to run.

    The NET_RX_BUSY_POLL is disabled by default (the system wide sysctls for
    poll/read are set to zero) so disable NET_RX_BUSY_POLL on RT to avoid wrong
    locking context on RT. Should this feature be considered useful on RT systems
    then it could be enabled again with proper locking and synchronisation.

    Signed-off-by: Sebastian Andrzej Siewior <bigeasy@linutronix.de>

diff --git a/net/Kconfig b/net/Kconfig
index 8cea808..32f1011 100644
--- a/net/Kconfig
+++ b/net/Kconfig
@@ -286,7 +286,7 @@ config CGROUP_NET_CLASSID

 config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL
        bool
-       default y
+       default y if !PREEMPT_RT

 config BQL
        bool

But since you removed the ice upgrade from the kernel upgrade, we don't have to worry about this issue here, as we now have an explanation as for why it is disabled by default.
Hi, Jim   CONFIG_NET_RX_BUSY_POLL is not set in 4.18 rt kernel. but it is set in 3.10 rt kernel.
Well, that's a red flag.  Check the commit history, see if there is a reason why we didn't set it in the 4.18 rt kernel.  It may well be an oversight.  Is it set in the std kernels?

Hi, Jim
config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL is like this in 5.10 rt kernel.
config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL
        bool
        default y if !PREEMPT_RT

it is this in 3.10 rt kernel.
config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL
        boolean
        default y

and it is set in the std kernel.  IT is this in all std kernel.
config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL
        bool
        default y

It is this in 4.18 rt kernel.
config NET_RX_BUSY_POLL
	bool
	default y if !PREEMPT_RT_FULL

then we can know the reason why they are different for 5.10, 4.18 and 3.10 kernel.

Help us to understand this better.  Did the new ice driver just start assuming that CONFIG_NET_RX_BUSY_POLL was defined?  What is the history of us using this config option, did we use it back in 3.10 rt?  How is this option related to NAPI?  I'm assuming that busy loop polling is probably bad in an rt context.

HAVE_AF_XDP_ZC_SUPPORT is defined when kernel version >= 4.20.0,  then the contents of src/ice_xsk.c will be compiled, it report error: implicit declaration of function 'napi_busy_loop';
there is not the issue in 3.10 kernel because HAVE_AF_XDP_ZC_SUPPORT is indef.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/fibre_chan.message: In my opinion we should be using "get_sysfs_wwid" method instead (like we do in iSCSI) as it is faster and more resilient.
nit: Assignment to wwn  should be added before the for loop, like we do with mpath_path

-1: This introduces a new bug for multipathed connections when all paths are down. Since we can't get the wwn using scsi_id we won't try to get the mpath_path and we won't try to flush the multipath, so in the end we will be removing the individual devices underneath the multipath DM, which will most likely lead to data loss.
Yes, it is, but if replase the get_scsi_wwn to get_sysfs_wwid, i think it won't introduces the bug. because get_sysfs_wwid is read the device file, this don't raise excepthion.

It will not be lost if we do the right thing, which is abort the operation.
Since we don't remove the underlying devices there is an opportunity for the network (or whatever is failing) to be fixed and the next disconnect call to succeed.
I think that, if all path was down, the flush multipath won't success, and the data will loss too.
-1: This should only be called if wwn is not already set, and we shouldn't set it to None on failure since we already do that on L340

-1: As mentioned on path #13 this introduces a regression where we could be saying that the detach was successful leaving a multipath device mapper in the system (leftover device) but removing all the individual paths.

This is not acceptable, on multipath flush failure the operation has to be aborted and we cannot proceed.
Thanks for review, i update it, if wwn is none, means all path was exception, then we can rasie an exception.
